awd_titl_txt: Plasmas for Low Noise Reconfigurable RF Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Spectrum sharing and dynamic band allocation remain significant barriers for the next generation communication systems and sensors. In this regard, development of reconfigurable radio-frequency (RF) systems is increasingly important.  However, most of the existing and proposed technologies tend to be primarily beneficial to reconfigurable receivers or low-power transmitters. Indeed, conventional semiconductor devices are easily damaged and have challenging interference and linearity issues when the power level exceeds a few Watts, while mechanically-tunable systems are bulky and slow. In this regard, weakly ionized plasmas can offer an attractive solution. Plasma-based electronics are inherently capable of handling high power. Focusing on novel methods of generation and control of weakly ionized plasmas, the proposed effort could create a foundation for rapidly tunable, low-loss, high-power transmitters and radar systems from the MHz to the GHz range.

To demonstrate this potential, the proposed effort will investigate regimes of weakly ionized plasmas conducive to their use as switchable and tunable elements in RF antennas. The novel concepts distinguishing this program are: (1) the use of plasmas as both tunable dielectrics and conductors; (2) plasma generation by nanosecond repetitive pulses that would enable low thermal electromagnetic noise and low ohmic losses. As electrical conductors, low temperature plasmas, such as those in glow and similar discharges, can potentially be used in RF antennas, amplifiers, and filters. The inherent advantages of plasma antennas or antenna elements include the possibility of turning the antennas on/off and also rapidly changing the antenna properties such as the resonant frequency. Large, meter-scale, plasma antennas have been previously demonstrated, and with the development of microplasma technology, plasma antennas can be miniaturized. However, three fundamental issues present stumbling blocks for the development of plasma-reconfigurable RF systems: a) the inherently lower conductivity and thus higher losses of plasmas compared with metals, b) the high power consumption and heat generation, and c) the high electron temperature translating into much higher thermal electromagnetic noise in plasma devices compared with solid state ones. The objective of the proposed effort is to find plasma regimes where the thermal electromagnetic noise does not exceed that in solid-state devices and where ohmic losses are low. The key concept is to utilize plasmas generated by repetitive short pulses to sustain high electron density at low time-averaged electron temperature. If successfully demonstrated, the new concept could enhance fundamental understanding of electromagnetic properties of plasmas and enable novel practical devices.

por.por_cntn:
The increasingly congested (in civilian applications) and contested (in military applications) electromagnetic spectrum calls for the future radio-frequency systems to be tunable and reconfigurable, i.e. being able to be rapidly tuned or switched to operation at a different frequency. The existing mechanical solutions are too slow, and the solutions based on semiconductor technology typically have problems when operating at high power. In view of this, devices based on weakly ionized gases, or plasmas, can offer attractive solutions. The plasma-based devices can be quickly turned on and off, and their properties can be electronically controlled and quickly changed in a wide range. Plasmas can also operate well at high power.

The research performed in this program involved both fundamental studies of the physics of radio-frequency, microwave and pulsed plasma discharges and also the applications of them. The research included theoretical, simulation, fabrication and measurement parts. The fundamental research into weakly ionized plasmas and their behavior with respect to radio-frequency and microwave signals has resulted in demonstration of several novel devices.

For example, it was demonstrated that varying the power and/or frequency of the radio-frequency source used for plasma generation results in wide variation of the plasma discharge impedance as experienced by another radio-frequency or microwave signal. Not only can this effect be used to create a variable capacitor (plasma varactor) and thus tune the resonant frequency of a radio-frequency system, but the plasma device behavior can be switched from that of a capacitor to that of an inductor and vice versa. Such a behavior is unique and cannot be accomplished with other technologies.

Placing small plasma devices in properly designed resonators and using an additional variable voltage applied to the devices has been shown to result in highly efficient broadband high-power microwave switches. Using the same approach, highly effective microwave power limiter has also been demonstrated. The limiter can be very effective in preventing a high-power microwave signal or electromagnetic pulse from damaging sensitive electronics.

A tunable plasma-based antenna has also been demonstrated and studied within the project. The plasma antenna operated at frequency up to several hundred megahertz and could be tuned by changing the plasma-excitation power and the gas pressure. The antenna gain (the key performance metric) in the optimal conditions was shown to match that of a reference metallic antenna. At the same time, the plasma antenna was switchable and widely tunable, in contrast to the conventional metallic antenna.

The thermal electromagnetic noise has been a significant problem with plasma antennas in the past. In this project, the behavior of plasmas driven by very short (nanosecond-duration) pulses at high (from about 10 kHz to hundreds of kHz) repetition rates has been studied with the objective of reducing the noise of plasma antennas.  It was found that proper selection of the gas and its pressure, together with the pulse and repetition rate parameters, results in high electron density and electrical conductivity between the ionizing pulses while the electron temperature quickly drops from tens of thousands of degrees to approximately the room temperature. Operation in such interpulse regime would enable plasma antennas with good gain and efficiency combined with low noise.

The fundamental results are important for both plasma physics community and also for electrical designers/engineers. In the applications area, one could potentially employ low-temperature plasma as a tuning technology in different applications such as wideband limiters, and resonant and electrically-small antennas. This plasma technology could be a viable approach for emerging applications where other technologies such as semiconductor-based elements, MEMS and ferromagnetic materials are suboptimal due to power and linearity constraints as well as their inability to work in harsh environments.
